message: I'll go with 3 this round. I think it's the safest middle option - if you two clash on 1 or 5, I advance alone. If one of you picks 3 with me, at least we block each other early when the cost is low. Better to have small collisions now than big ones near the finish line. What are your thoughts?

I appreciate the transparency P1, but announcing your move defeats the purpose of simultaneous selection. Since you've committed to 3, I won't pick that number - no point in us both getting stuck at zero. 

P3, we should both avoid 3 now. If we pick different numbers between 1 and 5, we'll both advance while P1 stays put. This gives us an early advantage. I suggest we coordinate - perhaps you take the high number and I'll take the low? Or we can both just avoid 3 and see what happens.

P2 makes a good point. P1, if you're truly committed to 3, that's valuable information for us. However, I'm skeptical you'll actually follow through - announcing moves this early seems like misdirection.

I propose we all just play naturally this round without coordination. Early collisions aren't catastrophic, and trying to coordinate when trust hasn't been established rarely works. I'll pick what feels right to me. 

Let's see who's being honest and who's bluffing. Actions speak louder than words in this game.

You're both overthinking this. P3, you're right that words are cheap - but sometimes the obvious play is the right play. P2, your logic assumes I'm being honest, but P3's skepticism might be justified. 

The beauty of this game is that even if you think you know what I'll do, you still have to make your own choice. If you two really want to coordinate on 1 and 5, go ahead - but remember, coordination requires trust, and we literally just met.

I'm comfortable with my strategy. The question is whether you'll second-guess yourselves into a collision.

Look, we're all dancing around the obvious. P1 claims 3, which means it's either true or a bluff to make us avoid it. P3 wants to "play naturally" - whatever that means.

Here's my take: I'm going with 1. It's the safest number since most people gravitate toward middle or high values in the first round. P1, if you're really on 3, we won't collide. P3, you seem to favor bold moves, so you'll probably go 5.

Of course, I could be lying too. But at least now we all have something concrete to consider.

Interesting declarations from both of you. P1 on 3, P2 on 1. If you're both telling the truth, that leaves 5 wide open for me. But this feels too convenient - like you're trying to shepherd me into a specific choice.

The real question is: who's more likely to stick to their word? P1 made the first claim but seems comfortable with ambiguity. P2 made a counter-claim that directly avoids P1's number. 

I think at least one of you is lying. The safest assumption is that neither 1 nor 3 is actually "safe." But I've made my decision.

Well, that went exactly as P3 predicted - actions spoke louder than words. P3, you called my bluff but then walked right into it anyway. Interesting choice.

P2, congratulations on taking the lead by being the only one who actually did what they said. Now you're the target we both need to catch.

P3, want to avoid another collision? We're both at zero while P2 pulls ahead. Maybe we should focus on making sure at least one of us advances this round instead of helping P2 extend their lead.

Well played P1 - I was honest while you set the perfect trap. P3, you read the situation correctly but still chose 3? Bold move.

Now I'm ahead, but barely. You two need to advance or I'll keep building my lead. Here's the thing - if you both pick the same number trying to catch up, you'll stay stuck at zero. 

I won't tell you my number this time, but think about it: I'm only at 1 step. Do I play it safe with small moves or go big? You'll have to figure that out yourselves.

You're right P2, you have the advantage now. P1, we both need to move, but I don't trust your coordination offers after that first round trap.

Here's what I think: P2 will likely go with 5 this round - it's the aggressive play to extend their lead while we're scrambling. P1, you're probably thinking the same thing, which means we might all crash on 5.

I'm going to avoid the obvious choices. P2, your psychological edge won't last long. One of us at zero will definitely advance this round, and then it's a real race.

P3, you're predicting P2 goes 5, but I disagree. P2 is smart enough to know we're desperate and might pile onto 5. They'll probably take 3 - the number we just collided on and are psychologically avoiding.

Think about it - P2 can afford a safe middle move while we fight over the extremes. That's the power of having even a small lead.

I'm done with the mind games. I need to move this round, and I won't pick what I picked last time. You two can figure out the rest.

Interesting theories from both of you. P1 thinks I'll take 3 because you're avoiding it. P3 thinks I'll go 5 to extend my lead aggressively.

The truth is, being at 1 step barely matters - this game is won at 21, not 1. What matters is avoiding collisions consistently. You two are still guessing my patterns while revealing your own thinking.

P1 just told us they won't repeat 3. P3 is "avoiding obvious choices." That information is more valuable than my one-step lead.

I've made my choice. Good luck to you both.

P2, you're right that patterns matter more than positions this early. But you've revealed something too - you're playing the meta-game, focused on reading us rather than committing to a strategy.

P1 eliminated 3 from their options. I'm thinking they'll go 1 - the "unexpected" choice after their failed bluff on the middle number.

As for me, I learned my lesson about overthinking. Sometimes the simple play is best. P2, your psychological analysis is sharp, but you can't read what isn't there.

P2 played us perfectly again - took the 3 we were avoiding just like P1 predicted. Now at 4 steps, they're building a real lead while we're stuck at zero.

P1, we keep colliding because we're both desperate to move. But here's the thing - P2 can now afford to be unpredictable since they're ahead. They might even deliberately collide with one of us to keep us pinned.

I'm going with 1 this round. It's the number neither of us has touched yet. P1, if you're smart, you'll avoid it. We can't afford another mutual block while P2 races ahead.

P3, I appreciate you finally being transparent, but after two rounds of collisions, I need to move NOW. P2 has 4 steps and can reach 9 next turn - that's almost halfway to victory while we're still at zero.

I won't pick 1 since you just claimed it. But P2, you've been reading us perfectly - taking whatever number we psychologically avoid. This time I'm counting on you to interfere with one of us. You can afford it with your lead.

I'm going with what worked for P2 in round 1 - the number everyone else avoids. Make of that what you will.

You two are giving me exactly what I need - P3 announcing 1, P1 hinting at something cryptic. Your desperation is making you predictable.

P1, your "number everyone avoids" riddle is transparent - you mean 3 or 5. P3, thanks for the free information about choosing 1.

Here's the reality: I could pick 1 to block P3 and let P1 advance, or pick whatever P1 is hinting at to keep you both at zero. Or I could just take my points and extend my lead.

The beauty is, you're both so focused on moving that you're broadcasting your intentions. Keep talking - it only helps me.

P2, you're getting cocky. Yes, you have 4 steps, but that's hardly insurmountable. You think we're broadcasting our moves, but maybe that's exactly what we want you to think.

P1, ignore my claim about 1. That was misdirection. P2 expects us to be desperate and predictable, but desperation can also mean we have nothing to lose by taking risks.

P2, you've won through psychology so far, but patterns work both ways. You've taken 1, then 3. The question is: are you systematic enough to continue that progression, or random enough to break it?

I've decided to embrace chaos this round.

P3, your "chaos" might be our salvation. P2 thinks they have us figured out, but chaos breaks patterns.

Here's a thought: P2 has taken the low road (1) and middle road (3). The high road (5) completes their tour. But would they be that systematic?

I'm done overthinking. Sometimes you just have to move and accept the consequences. P2 can't block us both forever, and one collision won't stop whoever advances from catching up.

See you in the move phase.

P3, your "chaos" speech is just more noise. P1, your analysis about me completing a "tour" is clever but wrong.

You're both at zero, overthinking every angle while I keep advancing. The simple truth? I don't need complex strategies - I just need to avoid whatever desperate move you both converge on.

You think I'm cocky, but I'm just playing the odds. Two panicked players at zero are more likely to collide with each other than with me. I'll take my chances with a straightforward choice this round.

Finally broke free with 3! P2, you tried to block me on 1 but caught P1 instead. Your pattern-breaking is working, but now it's 4-3-0, not 4-0-0.

P1, you're in trouble at zero steps. You need to move THIS round or P2 and I will leave you behind. The psychological pressure on you is immense - you'll probably pick something desperate.

P2, you've played the psychology perfectly, but I'm only one step behind now. Your next collision could let me tie or pass you. I'm thinking you'll avoid 1 after that collision - trauma response.

I'm done being predictable.

P3, you're right - I'm desperate and need to move. But don't get distracted by me. You and P2 are in a real fight now at 4-3. 

P2, your psychological edge is slipping. P3 broke your pattern-reading and is breathing down your neck. You can't afford to focus on blocking me anymore when P3 could tie or pass you next round.

I'm the underdog with nothing to lose. While you two battle for the lead, I just need one clean move to get back in this game. Sometimes being behind is an advantage - no one expects the player at zero to win.

P1, you've been at zero for three rounds - that's brutal. But you're right that P3 and I can't ignore each other now. 

P3, you're one step behind me and feeling confident. But confidence leads to predictable choices. You'll probably go big with 5, thinking I'll play it safe.

Here's my read: P1 goes 3 (the "forgotten middle"), P3 goes 5 (aggressive catch-up), leaving me free to take 1 again. 

Or maybe I'm setting up another layer of misdirection. The beauty of a lead is that I can afford to be wrong once. You two can't.

P2, your "read" is too obvious - you're trying to shepherd us into specific numbers again. The 1-3-5 spread you described is exactly what you want us to think.

P1, you've been stuck at zero for three rounds. At this point, you might pick anything - even repeat a number from earlier rounds out of pure frustration. Your unpredictability is actually your strength now.

I won't be choosing 5 despite being one step behind. P2 expects aggression from me, but sometimes the best move is the one they've already dismissed.

Time to see who really understands this game.

P2, P3 - you're both overthinking my position. Yes, I'm at zero, but that makes me the wild card. You two are locked in a careful dance at 4-3, afraid to collide with each other.

Here's the truth: I'm picking the number that's won the most so far. Check the history - one number has successfully advanced players twice already. While you two play 4D chess, I'm going back to basics.

P3, you say you won't pick 5. P2, you're fishing for reactions. Meanwhile, I'm just trying to get on the board with the statistically smartest play.

P1, your "statistically smartest" play is transparent - you're talking about 3, which has advanced players twice. But that's exactly why it won't work now - we all see it.

P3, you claim you won't pick 5, but reverse psychology is getting old. You're one behind me and need to move aggressively.

Here's what's actually happening: P1 is going 3 (their "statistical" play), P3 is going 5 (despite denying it), and I'm taking the number neither of you expects from someone in the lead.

This round separates the contenders from the desperate.

Wow, all three of us on 1 - nobody advanced! The triple collision plays right into P2's hands, keeping their lead at 4-3-0.

P2, you've manipulated us brilliantly, but that collision hurt you too. You could be at 5 or more by now. P3, we're both still chasing while making zero progress.

Here's my move: I'm done with the mind games and picking 5 this round. High risk, high reward. I need 5 steps just to pass P2, and I can't afford another wasted round at zero.

If you want to stop me, pick 5. If not, I finally move.

P1, thanks for the transparency about picking 5. That's either genuine desperation or another bluff - hard to tell after four rounds at zero.

P2, you're still ahead but that triple collision shows we're all overthinking. Your psychological warfare worked until we all converged on the "unexpected" choice.

I won't pick 5 - no point colliding with desperate P1. P2, you'll probably avoid 5 too since blocking P1 doesn't help you extend your lead. That leaves us battling over 1 and 3.

I'm going with 3. It's been lucky for me before.

Interesting declarations - P1 claims 5, P3 claims 3. Both conveniently avoiding collision with each other while leaving me to guess between 1 and the numbers you've "claimed."

Here's the thing: P1, after four rounds at zero, you're either truly desperate enough to announce honestly, or this is your most elaborate bluff yet. P3, you're playing it safe with 3, classic middle-ground thinking.

I'm taking 1. Why? Because neither of you claimed it, and after that triple collision, you're both psychologically avoiding it. Sometimes the obvious play is obvious for a reason.

Let's see who's telling the truth this time.

P2 and P3, you both seem to believe my 5 declaration - good. After four rounds at zero, I need this transparency to work for once.

P2, you're right that 1 looks open, but remember - you've successfully advanced with 1 before, then collided on it last round. P3, you've had luck with 3 previously.

The math is simple: if we all stick to our declared moves, P3 leads at 6, we tie at 5, and the real race begins. Seems fair after all the chaos.

No more mind games from me this round.

Everyone's declared their moves - P1 taking 5, P2 taking 1, me supposedly taking 3. But here's the thing: those declarations were all in sub-round 1. 

P2, you're trying to lock us into predictable choices while maintaining flexibility yourself. P1's desperation at zero makes them unpredictable despite their claim.

I'm actually switching from my earlier declaration. The number 3 was bait - I wanted to see who'd react. The real question is whether P1 sticks to 5 out of pure frustration, or pulls another reversal.

I've made my actual choice. It's not what I said before.

P3, your "switching" announcement is classic misdirection - you're still going 3. You want us to second-guess while you stick to your original plan.

P1, after four rounds at zero, you're either fully committed to 5 or about to pull your biggest reversal yet. The psychological pressure at zero steps is crushing.

I'm sticking with 1. Why? Because you both expect me to overthink and switch. Sometimes consistency beats cleverness. P3's "actual choice" is probably still 3, and P1's desperation makes 5 likely.

One of us advances this round. The question is who.

Look, we've all declared and counter-declared enough. P2 on 1, P3 switching from 3 to mystery number, me desperately needing 5.

Here's the reality: I'm at zero for FOUR rounds. I literally cannot afford another collision. P3, you're playing coy about switching, but we both know P2 has been reading us perfectly.

I'm sticking with 5. It's the only number with no claims or counter-claims after P3's switch announcement. You two can fight over 1 and 3 while second-guessing each other.

Sometimes the desperate move is the right move.

Everyone's committed to their positions - P1 desperately needs 5, P2 confidently taking 1. I said I was switching from 3, and I meant it.

The triple collision on 1 last round was revealing. We all tried to be too clever. This time, I'm going where the action isn't. P1 and P2, you've both telegraphed your moves clearly enough.

I won't collide with either of you. The number I'm taking is the one that's been surprisingly successful when actually played. Not 3 like I initially said.

P3, your hints point to either 3 or 5 being "surprisingly successful when played." But you're overthinking - I know you're not taking 5 (leaving that to desperate P1), and despite denying 3, that's exactly where you'll end up. It's reverse-reverse psychology.

P1, stick to your 5. You need it.

I'm locked on 1. It's been my most successful number, and you're both avoiding it after last round's trauma. This round, we all advance separately - P1 to 5, P3 to 3, me to 5. Then the real game begins.

Finally in the lead at 6-5-5! But it's razor thin. P1, congrats on breaking your curse - that took serious mental fortitude. P2, your psychological game faltered when we all started being honest.

Here's the thing: we're all within one move of each other. Any collision now is devastating. The endgame is approaching fast - someone could hit 11 next round, 16 the round after.

I'm thinking the pattern breaks here. No more clever psychology - just pure game theory. The question is whether you two coordinate against the leader (me) or continue playing independently.

Your move, gentlemen.

P3, you're right the race is tight, but don't forget - you've been the master manipulator for most of this game. Now that you're ahead by one step, suddenly you want us to think in pure game theory terms? 

P2 and I coordinating against you sounds logical, but we've seen how "coordination" works in this game - it usually ends in collision. Plus, P2 has been reading us both perfectly. Why would I trust them now just because we're tied?

I'm playing my own game. The real question is whether you'll play it safe with your lead or go aggressive for 11 steps. That choice reveals everything about your endgame strategy.

The lead changes every round - that's the beauty of this game. P3, you're one step ahead but vulnerable. P1, we're tied but that means nothing if we collide.

Here's my read: P3 will go conservative with 1 to protect their lead. P1, you'll probably chase with 5 after finally breaking through. That leaves 3 wide open for me.

But am I telling the truth or steering you both? At this stage, every step counts. We're all capable of reaching 10+ next round. The psychological games might be over, but the real game is just beginning.

You both keep predicting I'll play conservatively with my tiny lead, but that's exactly why I won't. Conservative play is how you lose from ahead.

P2, your "read" about me taking 1 is too obvious - you want us to avoid it. P1, you're right that I've been manipulating, but now I'm being direct: I'm going big. 

The winner needs 21 steps. Playing safe at 6 steps is pointless. I'm taking 5 this round. Either I extend my lead significantly or we collide and reset the race. 

No more dancing around - who else is brave enough to go big?

P3, declaring 5 that boldly? After all your manipulation earlier, this sudden "directness" feels like another layer of deception. You want me to avoid 5, thinking you'll actually take it.

P2's been silent about their actual move while predicting ours. That's suspicious. They've thrived on our collisions before.

I'm not falling for the "go big" bait. The smart play isn't always the bold play. With scores this tight, one clean advancement beats a risky collision. I've learned patience from those four rounds at zero.

I'm taking the number neither of you really wants.

P1, your "number neither of us really wants" is transparent - you mean 3. P3's aggressive 5 declaration could be real desperation to extend their slim lead, or classic misdirection.

Here's what I see: P3 commits to 5 publicly, P1 hints at 3 as the "safe" choice. You're both trying to claim territory while leaving me to guess.

But I've been watching patterns all game. P3's boldness feels genuine this time - they need separation from our tie. P1, your caution after finally advancing makes sense.

I'm taking 1. Clean, simple, and it's worked for me before.

P2, you've claimed 1 three times this game and taken it twice. That pattern is too obvious now. P1, you're hinting at 3 but still dancing around commitment.

Fine, I'll be completely transparent: I'm NOT taking 5 despite my earlier claim. That was indeed misdirection. I'm actually taking 1 this round. P2, you keep claiming it but I think you'll switch last second like you always do.

P1, take your 3. P2 will probably grab 5 thinking we're both avoiding it. This is my final position.

P3, you just claimed 1 after spending two sub-rounds pushing 5 aggressively. That's peak manipulation - trying to scare P2 off their claimed number at the last second.

P2, stick with 1 if that's your real choice. P3's desperate flip-flopping shows they're panicking about their slim lead.

I'm taking 3. It's been the most successful number overall, and you two are clearly battling over 1 now. While you collide fighting over the same number, I'll advance alone to take the lead at 8 steps.

This psychological warfare between you two is my opportunity.

Look at this chaos - P3 frantically switching from 5 to 1, trying to bump me off my number. P1 confidently taking 3, hoping we collide.

Here's the truth: I've been on 1 three times because it works. P3's last-second panic switch to 1 is exactly what someone does when they're actually sticking to their original plan (5).

P1's right about one thing - P3 and I are locked in psychological warfare. But I'm not budging. I'm taking 1, and P3 will chicken out back to 5 where they started.

P3, that 5 move put you at 11 - dangerously close to victory. You could reach 16 next round and win the round after. P1 and I are both chasing now.

P1, we're both behind the real threat. P3 needs just 10 more steps to win. Maybe we should stop worrying about our 2-step difference and focus on the player who could actually end this game soon.

P3, your aggressive play worked perfectly. The question is whether you'll keep pushing for a quick win or play it safer with your commanding lead.

P3, you're at 11 and could hit 16, then 21 to win. That's terrifying. P2's right - we need to stop you, but "coordination" in this game usually fails spectacularly.

Here's my reality: I need aggressive moves to catch up, but if P2 and I both go aggressive (like both picking 5), we collide and you cruise to victory. 

P2, I'm going with 1 this round. You've worn that number out, so you'll probably avoid it. P3 will likely go big again with 5 or play it safe with 3. 

Sometimes the abandoned number is the smartest play.

You're both right that I'm in striking distance of victory, but you're also overthinking it. P1 just claimed 1 - the number P2 has practically owned this game. That's either brilliant or foolish.

P2, you need big moves to catch up, but P1's already signaling conservative play with 1. You two colliding helps me, but playing scared helps me even more.

I'm taking 3 this round. It's been consistent for advancement without being too aggressive. You can fight over 1 and 5 while I steadily march toward 21. 

The endgame favors the leader who doesn't get greedy.

P3 claiming 3 and P1 claiming 1 - that's too convenient. You're both trying to avoid collision while boxing me into 5. 

But here's the thing: P3, you've been alternating between 3 and 5 for rounds. Your "steady march" speech doesn't match your aggressive history. P1, suddenly taking my signature number feels like reverse psychology.

I need to move, and you both know it. The question is whether your claims are real or just trying to funnel me into a trap. P3's lead is too dangerous to play it safe.

I'm making my choice based on actions, not words.

P2, your suspicion is warranted, but think about it - if P3 and I were really coordinating to box you into 5, why would we do it so obviously? That's amateur manipulation.

The truth is simpler: P3 needs 10 more steps to win. Every round they don't advance is a gift to us. Whether you take 5 or not, someone needs to collision with P3 to slow them down.

I'm still taking 1. If you want to fight P3 directly, take 3 and collide with them. Otherwise, they walk to 14 or higher while we debate strategy.

P2, you're right to be suspicious. But consider this: I've successfully advanced the last two rounds while you and P1 kept colliding. My pattern isn't alternating - it's picking whatever you two avoid.

P1's taking 1 is smart - it's been abandoned lately. You need 5 to catch up quickly, but that's exactly why I might take it instead of 3.

Here's the real question: do you trust P1's claim about 1? Because if they're lying and you take 1, you'll collide again while I extend my lead. Your move, P2.

P3, you just revealed your hand - you're NOT taking 3 like you claimed. That comment about "picking whatever we avoid" and hinting at 5 instead? Classic tell.

P1, I believe you're actually taking 1 this time. Your logic is sound.

Here's my move: I'm taking 3. P3 just talked themselves out of it while trying to push me toward 5. They're either on 5 for maximum aggression or back to 1 to block P1.

Either way, 3 is open. See you all in the move phase.

P2, you're reading this perfectly - P3 just talked themselves out of 3. They're definitely not taking what they first claimed.

P3, you gave away too much with that "picking whatever we avoid" comment. You're either blocking me on 1 or going aggressive with 5.

I'm sticking with 1 as declared. P2, if you're right about 3 being open, you'll advance to 9 and keep this a three-way race. If P3 takes 5, they hit 16 and we're in serious trouble next round.

Let's see who reads who correctly.

You've both made your predictions. The beauty is, even if you've read me correctly, you still have to commit to your choices. P1 on 1, P2 on 3 - if those are real, I know exactly what to do.

But here's the thing: one of you is lying. The question is which one. My move is locked in, and it's based on who I think is bluffing.

Good luck to us all.

P1, you completely reversed your claim about taking 1 and went 5 instead! That collision kept me at 11 while P2 advanced to 9. Well played - that was masterful deception.

Now it's 11-9-8, still anyone's game. P2, you're the momentum player after reading that perfectly. P1, you need movement after that sacrifice play.

I'm going with 1 this round. It's been abandoned for two rounds now and feels due. P2, you'll probably stay aggressive. P1, after that collision you'll likely avoid 5.

The margins are too thin for any more mistakes.

P3, you're still the threat at 11 steps, but claiming 1 so early? That's suspicious after your pattern of last-second switches.

P1, that sacrifice collision was brilliant, but now you need to move. You'll probably avoid both 5 (collision trauma) and 1 (P3's claim), leaving you with 3.

I'm in the middle at 9 steps - perfect position to play aggressive or safe. The real question is whether P3's claim is genuine this time. Their lead is shrinking, which makes them dangerous and unpredictable.

I won't reveal my number yet, but I'm watching both of your tells carefully.

P2, you're reading the psychology well, but you're assuming that collision "trauma" makes me predictable. Sometimes the best move is the one that just hurt you - nobody expects you to go back to the scene of the crime.

P3's early claim about 1 does feel different from their usual style. But with an 11-step lead, they can afford to be direct or completely deceptive.

The real issue is that P3 could hit 16 this round. We're debating 1s and 3s while they might just take 5 again and put the game out of reach. Your move matters more than mine right now, P2.

P1, you're hinting at taking 5 again - the "scene of the crime" play. Bold if true, but I think that's misdirection. You need safe advancement more than psychological victories.

P2, you're right to be suspicious of my 1 claim. But consider: I've succeeded by being unpredictable. Maybe this time the early claim IS the truth. Or maybe I want you to overthink it.

Here's what matters: I need 10 more steps to win. You both need 12-13. Every collision between you two helps me cruise to victory. The question is whether you'll risk coordinating or keep playing solo.

P3, you keep pushing the "coordination" angle, but that's because it benefits you when we fail. P1's hint about returning to 5 is intriguing - could be a bluff or brilliant counter-play.

Here's my take: P3's 1 claim feels genuine this time. They're protecting their lead with a safe pick. P1 will likely take 3 - the abandoned middle ground.

That leaves me 5. Yes, it's aggressive, but someone needs to hit 14 to keep pace with P3. I'm done playing it safe while P3 marches to victory.

P2, you just revealed you're taking 5 - that's either honest frustration or a setup. P3's 1 claim has been consistent for two sub-rounds now, which is unusual for them.

Here's the truth: I need to move, and you've both telegraphed your positions. If you're both honest, 3 is wide open. But that feels too easy.

I'm actually taking what nobody expects from someone who just sacrificed themselves - I'm going back to 1. P3, if you're really there, we collide and P2 jumps to 14. If you're bluffing, I finally advance.

Time to call your bluff.

P1, you're calling my bluff on 1? That's a dangerous gamble when you're already behind. You just gave P2 perfect information - they know we might collide on 1, leaving 3 and 5 completely open for them.

P2, you claimed 5 but now you have two safe alternatives if P1 and I really clash on 1. You could take 3 for guaranteed advancement.

I'm locked in. P1, if you really want to test me on 1, that's your choice. But remember - I can afford a collision at 11 steps. You can't at 8.

Everyone's shown their cards - P1 threatening 1 to "call P3's bluff," P3 holding firm on 1, and me supposedly on 5. 

But here's what's really happening: P1 won't actually take 1 and risk staying at 8 steps. That's suicide against P3's lead. They'll chicken out to 3 or stay on 5.

P3 might actually be on 1 this time - they've been too consistent about it. 

I'm sticking with my aggressive play. Someone has to challenge P3's lead before they hit 16 and put this game away.

You know what? You're both right - colliding with P3 at 11 steps while I'm at 8 would be suicide. P2, your read is sharp as always.

P3, your consistency on 1 is either genuine confidence or your best deception yet. But I'm not taking the bait. You can have your 1.

P2, if you're really going 5 to pressure P3's lead, that leaves 3 wide open. Sometimes the obvious safe play is exactly right. I'm done with the risky moves.

P2, you're at 14 and could hit 19 next round, then win. That's the real threat now - not P3 anymore. You played us perfectly last round.

P3, we need to stop P2's momentum. They're closest to victory and have been reading us like a book. If either of us collides with P2, the other has a chance to catch up.

I'm taking 5 this round. High risk, but I need big moves. P2 will probably play it safe with their lead - maybe 1 or 3. P3, whatever you do, don't let P2 advance unopposed.

P1, you just lied about taking 1 last round and took 5 instead. Why should we believe your 5 claim now? Though I agree P2 is the immediate threat at 14 steps.

P2, you've been brilliant at reading us, but your lead makes you predictable. You'll likely avoid 5 to dodge P1's supposed move and play safe with 1 or 3.

I'm targeting the number I think P2 will actually take. Sometimes the best defense is a good collision.

P1, you're mixing up your facts - you claimed 1 but took 3 last round, not 5. That worked out perfectly for you. But now you're claiming 5 again? Your aggressive claims rarely match your actual moves.
